ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A thorough grammatical and lexical knowledge of basic Old English grammar, translation skills, and also exposure to key texts from most major genres of Old English literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was incredible- Professor Thornbury used a textbook she herself designed, compiled, and authored, and it was as lucid and straightforward an introduction to a medieval language as any I've encountered. Class was very well structured, involving ironing out the grammatical and lexical concepts covered in the reading, going over the homework, and then a later class activity, such as sight translation. There was also a great creative component to this course, in which we all composed poems in Old English and presented them in class- a wonderful assignment which really forced me to get down into the weeds of Old English metrics and lexis. I honestly have no weaknesses to point out- it was wonderful!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely- it's a great way to gain insight into early medieval literature, and also a wonderful avenue for getting a language requirement done. I think the language part of the Department of English is a crucial place to get in touch with the history of the language, and to trace its growth from there on out, and Professor Thornbury's class offers a rigorous but incredibly generous and open-ended place for that knowledge to be garnered. I would recommend it to anyone, in or out of the department, medieval requirement or no.
